ngang.name: Mid-level (ngang)
ngang.description: Mid-level tone, even pitch. Neutral, flat, unmarked.
ngang.pronunciation: Steady **mid-level** pitch. Neutral and even — like a sustained, flat note.
ngang.analogy: The **pitch** of a calm, declarative statement.

sắc.name: Rising (sắc)
sắc.description: High-rising tone, starts mid and rises sharply. Energetic, bright.
sắc.pronunciation: Starts mid and rises **quickly to a high pitch**.
sắc.analogy: Like asking a **surprised, brief question** in English: 'Ah?!'

huyền.name: Falling (huyền)
huyền.description: Low-falling tone, starts mid and falls. Calm, soft.
huyền.pronunciation: Starts mid then **falls to a low pitch**; sounds calm or drawn-down.
huyền.analogy: The **pitch** when you express boredom or resignation: 'Ugh...'

hỏi.name: Dipping-rising (hỏi)
hỏi.description: Mid dipping tone, falls then rises slightly. Doubtful, questioning.
hỏi.pronunciation: A short, noticeable **dip in pitch followed by a slight rise**.
hỏi.analogy: The **questioning** intonation of 'Uh-huh?' (meaning 'What did you say?')
hỏi.notes: Often simplified to a low-fall or low-level pitch in rapid Northern speech.

ngã.name: Creaky rising (ngã)
ngã.description: Creaky rising tone, mid with glottal break then rising. Emphatic.
ngã.pronunciation: Rising pitch but with **creaky voice** or a **glottal catch/break** in the middle.
ngã.analogy: Similar to the 'Hỏi' tone but with a **choking or tight throat** sound before the rise. It is often perceived as more emphatic.
ngã.notes: In Hanoi Vietnamese, this tone is often realized as a high, sustained pitch with glottalization.

nặng.name: Heavy / Low glottalized (nặng)
nặng.description: Low, short, heavy tone with glottal stop. Abrupt, forceful.
nặng.pronunciation: Starts low, **drops abruptly**, and is **cut off** by glottal constriction (a catch in the throat).
nặng.analogy: A short, sharp grunt of **emphasis** or realization, like 'Oh!'
